lines.text: Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK, young YORK, QUEEN ELIZABETH, and the DUCHESS OF YORK

lines.speaker: archbishop of york
lines.text: Last night, I hear, they lay at Northampton; At Stony-Stratford will they be to-night: To-morrow, or next day, they will be here.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: I long with all my heart to see the prince: I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: But I hear, no; they say my son of York Hath almost overta'en him in his growth.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Ay, mother; but I would not have it so.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: Why, my young cousin, it is good to grow.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Grandam, one night, as we did sit at supper, My uncle Rivers talk'd how I did grow More than my brother: 'Ay,' quoth my uncle Gloucester, 'Small herbs have grace, great weeds do grow apace:' And since, methinks, I would not grow so fast, Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold In him that did object the same to thee; He was the wretched'st thing when he was young, So long a-growing and so leisurely, That, if this rule were true, he should be gracious.

lines.speaker: archbishop of york
lines.text: Why, madam, so, no doubt, he is.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Now, by my troth, if I had been remember'd, I could have given my uncle's grace a flout, To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: How, my pretty York? I pray thee, let me hear it.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old 'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth. Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: I pray thee, pretty York, who told thee this?

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: Grandam, his nurse.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: His nurse! why, she was dead ere thou wert born.

lines.speaker: york
lines.text: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: A parlous boy: go to, you are too shrewd.

lines.speaker: archbishop of york
lines.text: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: Pitchers have ears.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: archbishop of york
lines.text: Here comes a messenger. What news?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to unfold.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: How fares the prince?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Well, madam, and in health.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: What is thy news then?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret, With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: Who hath committed them?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: The mighty dukes Gloucester and Buckingham.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: For what offence?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed; Why or for what these nobles were committed Is all unknown to me, my gracious lady.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: Ay me, I see the downfall of our house! The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind; Insulting tyranny begins to jet Upon the innocent and aweless throne: Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre! I see, as in a map, the end of all.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days, How many of you have mine eyes beheld! My husband lost his life to get the crown; And often up and down my sons were toss'd, For me to joy and weep their gain and loss: And being seated, and domestic broils Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors. Make war upon themselves; blood against blood, Self against self: O, preposterous And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen; Or let me die, to look on death no more!

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary. Madam, farewell.

lines.speaker: duchess of york
lines.text: I'll go along with you.

lines.speaker: queen elizabeth
lines.text: You have no cause.

lines.speaker: archbishop of york
lines.text: My gracious lady, go; And thither bear your treasure and your goods. For my part, I'll resign unto your grace The seal I keep: and so betide to me As well I tender you and all of yours! Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.
Exeunt
